[[Image:len-terry-wiles.jpg|thumb|right|Len and Terry Wiles c.1970]] {{for|the Christian minister|Crossroads Community Cathedral}} '''Terrence 'Terry' Wiles''' (born January 12, 1962) was one of the most disabled [[thalidomide]] babies born in the UK. He has since become known internationally through the television drama ''On Giant's Shoulders'' and the best-selling book of the same name.
==Early life== Originally named Andrew, Wiles was born in [[Peterborough]], [[England]], to a [[prostitute]] mother and a visiting [[African American]] father.<ref>[http://www.gordonmoyes.com/2007/08/08/breaking-barriers/] Gordon Moyes 'Breaking Barriers'</ref> During her pregnancy Andrew's mother took [[thalidomide]] to combat her morning sickness, resulting in his severe disabilities at birth.
Unable to cope, Andrew's mother put him into care. He met Leonard and Hazel Wiles at Chailey Hospital in [[Sussex]] in October 1967, and after initial opposition from his birth mother and [[Social Services]], Leonard and Hazel were able to [[Adoption|adopt]] the young Andrew. As part of his fresh start with his new parents, Andrew decided to change his name to Terrence Wiles.<ref name=giants>On Giant's Shoulders : the story of Terry Wiles by Marjorie Wallace and Michael Robson Times Books, London 1976 ISBN 0723001464</ref>
Over the years Len Wiles, who was technically-minded and helped to design military equipment during [[World War II]], built a series of 'Supercars' for Terry, based on the [[forklift truck]], which enabled Terry to both augment his height and move around freely for the first time.<ref name=giants/>
Wiles suffered a nervous breakdown due to abuse at his [[secondary school]] [[St Neots Community College|Ernulf Community College]] in [[St. Neots]], where on one occasion some students put him in a bag and dragged him around a room. He left the school to study at a [[polytechnic (United Kingdom)|polytechnic]].<ref name=fight>'Fight For Love' Channel 4 documentary 1997</ref>
==''On Giant's Shoulders''== Then aged 19, Wiles played himself in a [[1979]] [[BBC]] television ''Play of the Week'' entitled ''On Giant's Shoulders'', starring [[Judi Dench]] as Hazel Wiles and [[Bryan Pringle]] as Leonard Wiles.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0079663/] 'On Giant's Shoulders' on the Internet Movie Database</ref> The film was based on [[Marjorie Wallace (SANE)|Marjorie Wallace]] and Michael Robson's book about Wiles' life of the same name published in 1976.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/article1086514.ece] 'The Times' online November 5, 2006</ref>
==Recent years== After Wiles received financial compensation for his birth defects he and his adoptive parents [[emigrated]] to [[New Zealand]].
Later, Wiles met Robyn, a married nurse who left her husband to be with him. The couple faced a great deal of opposition from both families; Wiles' parents believed that Robyn was only interested in his money, the financial payout that he had received from the thalidomide manufacturers ([[Distillers Company]]). However, they married in 1991 and began to live together in [[Hamilton, New Zealand]]. Len and Hazel Wiles severed all contact with the couple.<ref>Pilger, John (ed.). ''Tell Me No Lies: Investigative Journalism and its Triumphs''</ref> Leonard Wiles died in 1996.
Terry and his wife continue to live in Hamilton, where Terry counsels others with disabilities. In 1997 [[Channel 4]] filmed Terry and Robyn in New Zealand for a [[Documentary film|documentary]] entitled ''Fight For Love''.<ref name=fight/><ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1015982/] 'Fight For Love' on the Internet Movie Database</ref>
